Description: Five fragments of a silk fabric; Includes a repeating pattern of motifs of lanceolate leaves with bases (similar to the ace of spades); Now discoloured brown but originally fold-coloured on a purple ground; Pattern perpendicular to warp, vertical repeat is 5.5cms, widthways repeat is 5.25cms; On fragment (a) is a fringe of twisted threads beyond a white border stripe; Technique of a wet-faced compund 1:2 twill, single ends in main warp, S twill, 2 lats, band of simple twill with grouped picks; Warp: Z twist, c.30 tpc; Weft: no twist, S-spun, c.50 passes per cm (ie: 100 tpc); Edges: on (a) is a fringe of warp threads, S twisted into cords, then 3 are Z twisted, 12cms long; on (b) the remains of selvedge, thick linen cord lines, now mostly perished; Sewing: remains of deep pink, Z twist, silk sewing thread on (b), from a diagonal seam;
Curator's comments: Probably acquired with OA.10722; Previous location Gallery 41, case 25; Cuts made after excavation; Other fragments of the same textile are spread around and include V&A (2 pieces, 2191-1900, 337-1887), Musee Historique des Tissus, Lyon (25.223), Deutsches Textilmuseum, Knedolf? and Whitworth Art Gallery, Manchester; Other parallels include a small fragment of a similar silk with a green ground in the treasury at Beromunster (B.Schmedding, Mithelalterliche Textilien in Kirchen und Klostern der Schweiz, Bern, 1978, no.2) and a silk and wool fragment in the treasury of Favemontiers (Tissn et vetement, ex.cat, Guiry-en-vexin, 1986, pl.12, B7); For a similar design in use see the mosaic panel with Justinian, San Vitale, Ravenna, 1st complete soldier from the left; Information from Hero Granger-Taylor (11.7.1989)
R Forrer, 'Romanische und Byzantinische seider-textilien,' Strasburg, 1891, PL VIII A F Kendrick, 'Catalogue of Textiles from Burying-Grounds in Egypt,' V & A, London, 1922, nos. 840, 841.
